 Actually, you don't need infinity to determine the area under a curve or obtain values for vlume and surface area. What you need is a metric and the metric induces a topology. You can then talk about length inside this topology and cross the space of the topology to get other topologies where area and volume are meaningful. You can have area and volume inside a topology of finite elements, so infinity is not needed at all!

 Mathematically infinity becomes an unusual subject because we can find infinity of different sizes. It's easy for many to imagine the number line going forever since you can always add one to any number you stop at. You can never reach the end. There is also an infinite number of infinite sets between any two numbers on that line. For any number n we can write n/(n+1), n/(n+2), n/(n+3) and so on to infinity. For n=1 we have: 1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/5, ... For n=2: 2/3, 2/4, 2/5, 2/6, .... and so on. As n is incremented we can generate and infinite set of infinite sets between 0 and 1 and this will not even include any of the irrational numbers between 0 and 1 because of of the members of these sets will be the ratio of 2 integers. This is still a smaller infinity than the number line itself or the infinite numbers of infinite sets that could be found anywhere on it.
 
 Just a little food for thought....
